column8: de Vries (2019), p34-36 https://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid:be8cbe0a-28ec-4bd9-8ad0-648de04649b8?collection=education, updated following discussions with de Vries on 11/05/2022 and based on no SCR
column10: NOx emissions from use of NH3/H2 blends as a maritime transport fuel in ICE engines may be the same as for the fossil fuels they replace (eg diesel). H2 Fuel cells may also be used for shipping which have no tail pipe emissions

column8: Shen et al (2017) doi: 10.1016/j.egypro.2017.03.750, (high end) and https://publications.jrc.ec.europa.eu/repository/handle/JRC21207 table A1, and Shirkey et al (2021) https://doi.org/10.3390/en14092633
column10: NOx emissions from H2/NH3 blends are an issue to be addressed. These are assumed to be limited by regulation to current levels. Actual NOx emissions in China are used as a proxy for average global NOx emissions, in the high case, and average NOx emissions from CH4 (EEA EU Default) is used in for the low case, noting this varies widely within and across countries.

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf Table 3.6.5
column10: NOx emissions from H2/NH3-powered aircraft may be lower than jetfuel if there is greater capacity to control the combustion conditions but at this stage it is uncertain. Talal Yusaf et al. (2022) . https://doi.org/10.3390/su14010548, and McKinsey & Company (2020) https://www.fch.europa.eu/sites/default/files/FCH%20Docs/20200507_Hydrogen%20Powered%20Aviation%20report_FINAL%20web%20%28ID%208706035%29.pdf
Assumed to be via fuel cells. No tail pipe emissions from fuel cells

column10: NOx emissions from H2/NH3 blends are an issue to be addressed. These are assumed to be limited by regulation to current levels. Actual NOx emissions in China are used as a proxy for average global NOx emissions, although these vary widely.

McKinsey & Company (2020) https://www.fch.europa.eu/sites/default/files/FCH%20Docs/20200507_Hydrogen%20Powered%20Aviation%20report_FINAL%20web%20%28ID%208706035%29.pdf

column8:
Mounam-Rousselle and Brequigny (2020) https://doi.org/10.3389/fmech.2020.00070 https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf Table 3.2.2 (value for Gasoline low mileage light light duty vehicles) and S3.19 (Footnote 11) Notes that the ratio of N2O/NOx emissions suggested in the literature is 0.1-0.25 (Lipmann and
Delucchi, 2002 and Behrentz, 2003)
column10: Proposing to use simple average from IPCC guidelines noting the wide range depending on vehicle type (see eg EU road vehicle emissions factors) https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/1-energy/1-a-combustion/road-transport-appendix-4-emission/view)

column8: Kristensen (2010) 'Energy demand and exhaust gas emissions of marine engines' is source of emissions factors, De Vries (2019) and email communication with author) and https://www.itf-oecd.org/sites/default/files/docs/man-es-decarbonisation-options-towards_2050.pdf
column10: CNG may be a transition fuel, and could offer 90% reduciton in NOx emissions compared to heavy fuel oil as a bunker fuel

column8: High estimate is from EU Defualt EMEP/EEA (2019) https://www.eea.europa.eu//publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019, Table 3.4. Low estimate is from US estimate in 2019 from Shirkey et al 2021 (https://doi.org/10.3390/en14092633)
column10: NOx emissions from LNG vary widely across countries. Propose using the EU default

column8: Soler (2020), Role of E-fuels in European Transport Sytem - literature Review https://www.concawe.eu/wp-content/uploads/Rpt_19-14.pdf
column10: Synthetic methane not envisaged as an aviation fuel - Have not found estimates of emissions factors from synthetic methane in aviation

column8:
https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf S3.19 (Footnote 11) Notes that the ratio of N2O/NOx emissions suggested in the literature is 0.1-0.25 (Lipmann and
Delucchi, 2002 and Behrentz, 2003)
column10: Same as CNG. Wide range depending on vehicle type (see eg EU road vehicle emissions factors https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/1-energy/1-a-combustion/road-transport-appendix-4-emission/view)

column8: Based on De Vries (2019) and email exchange with author for Methanol, and Timko et al (2011) doi.org/10.4271/2003-01-0763 and Alleman and McCormick (2003) https://doi.org/10.4271/2003-01-0763
column10: Based on De Vries (2019) and email exchange with author for Methanol. This range is not inconsistent with range from other sources for other applications eg Allen & McCormick (2003) literature review finds average NOx exhaust emissions from FT fuels are 13% lower than for conventional diesel, noting that the emissions levels are very engine dependent

column8: No source
column10: Further research required. Limited information on synthetic fuels in power generation. NOx likely to depend on fuel. Ommitted from this study given IEA WEO (2021) scenarios not projecting material SF for power generation to 2050. NOx emissions from FT fuels are not substantially different from LNG fuels according to some studies. Timko et al (2011)https://doi.org/10.1080/00102202.2011.581717 finds NOx emissions are reduced by 10% (100% FT fuel) and 5% (50% FT fuel blend), Braun-Unkhoff et al. (2018) DOI 10.1007/s13272-016-0230-3. Styring et al (2021) finds dimethylether

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf, Table 3.6.5 and Timko et al. (2011) https://doi.org/10.1080/00102202.2011.581717
column10: NOx emissions from FT fuels are not substantially different from jet fuels according to some studies. Timko et al (2011) finds NOx emissions are reduced by 10% (100% FT fuel) and 5% (50% FT fuel blend), Braun-Unkhoff et al. (2018) DOI 10.1007/s13272-016-0230-3https://doi.org/10.1080/00102202.2011.581717

column8: Timko et al (2011) doi.org/10.4271/2003-01-0763 and Alleman and McCormick (2003) https://doi.org/10.4271/2003-01-0763 and IPCC (2006) https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf
column10: NOx emissions from FT-Diesel fuels are on average 13% lower compared to conventional diesel fuels (Alleman and McCormick (2003)). So adopting a 13% reduction on IPCC diesel road transport default emissions factors (where consistent with sectino 3.19 footnote 11 NOx is generally 0.1-0.25 of N2O emissions)

column8: Lowed bound is from Table 3 Pavlenko (2020) https://theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/Climate_implications_LNG_marinefuel_01282020.pdf , and upper bound is from Lindstad (2020) http://dx.doi.org/10.3390/su12218793 (for a 4 stroke engine) supported by de Vries - email exchange with author
column10: Drawing on studies rather than IPCC defaults as conversion to LNG for maritime has been relatively receent. Value cited is for 4 Stroke engine (consistent with Pavlenko (2020) view on likely uptake), but different engines and fuel types give different emissions factors from eg -0.25 g/KWh for a 2 stroke dual fuel to 5.5g/Kwh for a 4 stroke dual fuel)

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_2_Ch2_Stationary_Combustion.pdf Table 2.2
column10: Combustion emissions are same as natural gas . Use default values from IPCC (2006). Uncertainty range is 0.3-3.0 and default is 1. High emissions factor uses upper bound of range and low emissions factor is the default

column8: Soler (2020), Role of E-fuels in European Transport Sytem - literature Review https://www.concawe.eu/wp-content/uploads/Rpt_19-14.pdf,
column10: Synthetic methane not envisaged as an aviation fuel in IEA WEO (2021) so omitted from this study

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf (Table 3.2.2 - noting wide uncertainty range (50-1540 kg/TJ) - s3.23), and Moritz Mottschall (2020) https://theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/LNG-in-trucks_May2020.pdf
column10: Sames as natural gas. Default value is used, but uncertainty range is high (Lower bound 50, Upper bound 1,540)

CH4 and N20 emissions from synthetic fuel depend on the fuel type and vehicle and are highly uncertain. This is true also for the fossil fuels they replace see IPCC (2006) discussion regarding default emissions factors. CH30H is considered a likely synthetic fuel for maritime transport and will not emit CH4 when combusted (De Vries 2019 and email exchanges with the author)

Likely to depend on specific fuel. Further research required. Not included in this study given they will not impact results because SF is not projected to be material source of fuel for stationary energy in IEA WEO 2021 scenarios

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf s 3.56, Table 3.6.5 Default value for all fuels, noting wide uncertainty range (-57% to +100%)
column10: CH4 and N20 emissions from synthetic fuel depend on the fuel type and vehicle and are highly uncertain. This is true also for the fossil fuels they replace see IPCC (2006) discussion regarding default emissions factors.But aviation fuels and modern engines emit little or no N20 or CH4 (IPCC Guidelines (2006) p 3.56, so this is used as the default low scenario, given no such emissions are discussed by Timko (2011) or Yusaf et al (2022) in relation to synthetic fuels

Likely to depend on specific fuel. Further research required. Not included in this study given they will not impact results because SF is not projected to be material source of fuel for stationary energy in IEA WEO 2021 scenarios
No tail pipe emissions if H2 from Fuel Cell. If in a NH3/H2 blend the N20 emissions are all atrributed to NH3

column8: None at this stage
column10: N20 can be an issue in H2 combustion when other gases, including N2O or NH3 are added to the flame to control combustion temperatures See Razus et al (2022) https://doi.org/10.3390/pr10051032. This remains an issue for further research in practical H2 combustion conditions. .

column10: Wide range possible from below detection level (Ito et al 2019) to many times higher Mashruk et al 2022, depending on combustion conditions
If from fuel cell, further research required

column8: Lower bound is based on Pavlenko (2020) https://theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/Climate_implications_LNG_marinefuel_01282020.pdf table 3 - sourced to GREET (2018). Upper bound is based on ratio of N2O from CH4 compared to MGO in email exchange with de Vries in May 2022, and Fridell et al 2020 https://www.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:1601021/FULLTEXT01.pdf) estimates of emissions from international shipping
https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_2_Ch2_Stationary_Combustion.pdf, table 2.2
column10: IPCC Emissions Factors for N20 from natural gas combustion Tier 1 Emission Factor - noting there is a wide range (0.03-0.3), The high case adopts the top of this range and the low adopts the default

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf
column10: CH4 Not used for aviation so emissions factors are not available. Ommitted from this study given IEA WE (2021) not projecting e-CH4 as aviation fuel

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf
column10: N2O default emissions for natural gas used - noting these are depend on the vehicle and there is a wide range (1-77)

column8: Pavlenko et al (2020) table 3 and table 4, which is sourced to GREET (2018) and gives similar estimates to De Vries (2019) and email exchange with author https://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid:be8cbe0a-28ec-4bd9-8ad0-648de04649b8?collection=education
column10: CH4 and N20 emissions from synthetic fuel depend on the fuel type and vehicle and are highly uncertain. This is true also for the fossil fuels they replace see IPCC (2006) discussion regarding default emissions factors. CH30H is considered a likely synthetic fuel for maritime transport may emit similar N2O as marine gas oil (De Vries 2019 and email exchanges with the author), but further research is needed.

CH4 and N20 emissions from synthetic fuel depend on the fuel type and vehicle and are highly uncertain.Ommitted from this study given IEA WEO (2021) is not projecting material use of SF for stationary energy

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf s 3.56, Table 3.6.5 Default value for all fuels, noting wide uncertainty range (-70%-+150%)

column8: https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_3_Ch3_Mobile_Combustion.pdf Table 3.2.2 Upper bound is default value for diesel, lower bound is dimethyl ether (0) from Styring et al (2021)
column10: NOx from SF will vary by fuel - estimate of practically 0 is for dimethylether (Styring et al 2021) but some synthetic petrol emit similar NOx to fossil petrol alternatives (T & E) , and synthetic diesel may emit ~13% less NOx than conventional diesel (Alleman & McCormack (2003))
